metadata.case_name: Buckingham Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Venkatiah & Madras Labour Union

facts.text: Appellant Buckingham Carnatic Co. Ltd. is a company registered under Indian Companies Act with registered office at Madras and a Textile Mill in Madras City employing 14,000 workmen.
Respondent Venkatiah went on leave for six days from January 10, 1957; taking intervening holidays, leave expired on January 18, 1957.
Venkatiah did not join duty on January 19, 1957, and remained absent without leave without any communication for extension.

On March 11, 1957, Venkatiah sent a letter to appellant stating he suffered from fever and dysentery after reaching village near Kanigiri, treated by Civil Assistant Surgeon, Kanigiri; accompanied by certificate stating chronic malaria and dysentery from January 15 to March 7, 1957.
Venkatiah appeared before Manager; sent to Senior Medical Officer of appellant for examination; Officer unable to confirm illness for nearly two months.
On March 23, 1957, appellant refused to reinstate Venkatiah as explanation for absence unsatisfactory; treated under Standing Order No. 8(ii).

Around June 15, 1957, Venkatiah obtained cash sickness benefit from Employees State Insurance Corporation for period covered by medical certificate; Regional Director accepted certificate as alternative evidence; Rs. 82-14-00 paid.
Respondent Union took up Venkatiah's case; referred for adjudication to Labour Court at Madras as industrial dispute S.P.O. No. A-5411 of 1958.

Labour Court rejected appellant's objection on invalidity of reference; held termination justified under Standing Orders but inconsistent with s.73 ESI Act; directed reinstatement within two weeks without back-wages but with continuity of service.
Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 716 of 1958 in Madras High Court; allowed by Mr. Justice Balkrishna Ayyar who held s.73 inapplicable and award based on sympathy.
Respondents filed Letters Patent Appeal No. 82 of 1959; Division Bench allowed it, restored Labour Court award holding s.73 applicable and refusal to reinstate illegal and unfair.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

Standing Order No. 8(ii): Absent without leave for eight consecutive working days deemed to have left service without notice; if explanation satisfactory, converted to leave without pay; if due to sickness proved to satisfaction, medical leave.

legal_issues.text: True scope and effect of provisions contained in s.73 of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948.
Whether termination of service under Standing Order 8(ii) for absence without leave contravenes s.73 of the Act.
Whether appellant acted fairly in rejecting Venkatiah's medical certificate and explanation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Case falls squarely within Standing Order 8(ii); absence for eight consecutive days without leave deems termination of contract; explanation unsatisfactory based on company's Medical Officer opinion.
S.73 prohibits punitive action during period of illness but does not apply to automatic termination under Standing Order 8(ii) which is not a positive act of discharge or punishment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948 s.73; s.85(d)

petitioner_arguments.text: Sickness benefit received after period of alleged illness; s.73(1) inapplicable as no benefit received during illness.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant did not properly discharge obligation of examining explanation reasonably; refusal to accept medical certificate unfair.
S.73 applies; prohibits dismissal/discharge during period employee in receipt of sickness benefit; since benefit granted, termination illegal.
Anomalous for ESI Corporation to accept illness for benefits but employer reject for Standing Order; s.73 binds employer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948 s.73; Regulations under Act

court_reasoning.text: Standing Order 8(ii) deems absence for eight consecutive days without leave as termination of contract; explanation opportunity provided, but if unsatisfactory, termination stands; binding as statutory terms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certified Standing Orders prevail over common law; no need for enquiry as under misconduct clause.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court correctly found management justified under Standing Orders alone; High Court erred in interfering without mala fides allegation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Propriety of rejecting certificate for management to decide.

court_reasoning.text: S.73(1) prohibits employer from dismissing/discharging/punishing during period employee in receipt of sickness benefit (period of illness); moratorium on punitive actions during illness if benefit received.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prohibition not confined to sickness-related misconduct but all; however, termination here not during illness period.

court_reasoning.text: Termination under SO 8(ii) automatic from absence, not positive act/order of employer; 'discharge' in s.73 implies decision embodied in order.
ESI acceptance of certificate under proviso to Reg.53 not binding on employer; no provision compels employer to accept.

holdings.text: S.73 ESI Act prohibits punitive actions (dismissal, discharge etc.) during period of employee's illness for which sickness benefit received, but applies only to positive acts/orders, not automatic termination under Standing Order 8(ii).
Termination under SO 8(ii) valid; does not contravene s.73.

statutes_cited.name: Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits employer from dismissing/discharging/punishing during sickness benefit period; contravention penal; interpreted as not covering automatic termination under Standing Orders.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act (implied)
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems prolonged absence without leave as termination; binding statutory terms of service.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; writ jurisdiction limits.

statutes_cited.name: Employees' State Insurance (General) Regulations, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Certification and claims for sickness benefit; proviso allows alternative evidence.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Division Bench of Madras High Court set aside; order of single Judge restored. Appellant to reinstate Venkatiah on terms of Labour Court award (without back-wages, continuity of service) as assured in court.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of single Judge order quashing Labour Court award; reinstatement recommended by appellant.

key_quotes.text: "No employer shall dismiss, discharge, or reduce or otherwise punish an employee during the period the employee is in receipt of sickness benefit..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Verbatim s.73(1) ESI Act; core provision interpreted.

key_quotes.text: "...the plain object of the clause is to put a sort of a moratorium against punitive actions during the pendency of the employees illness."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "...termination of the employees services follows automatically... from a Standing Order... such termination is not the result of any positive act or order on the part of the employer..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
